advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> STRAPPING MAN!</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> A compact problem-solving add for engineers, statisticians, scientists and financial and business analysts. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> ...You will get more performances than with the IBM PC, the Apple II, TRS80 Model II or TRS80 Model III along with software support of TRSDOS or CP/M, the two most widely used operating systems. This means you, the user, can select from the largest base of business or personal software... <font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEB. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977) #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert (May 1977) introduced the <b>System 16</b>, same as assembled System 7 with 16 Kb of RAM. ($1995)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST C-10 AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #10</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional adhesive sticker of the RC 700 Piccolo... What a visionary thought!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORIGINAL ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The history of the Galaksija started with a magazine article - called "Raèunara u vašoj kuæi" (computers in your home) by Dejan Ristanoviæ. This magazine was the first issue of the magazine series called later "Raèunara". This first issue included an article about the do-if-yourself computer "Galaksija" written by Voja Antonic. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source : <a href="http://www.homecomputer.de/" target="_blank">HomeComputerMuseum.de</a></font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This promotional picture was used to emphasize the programming assets of the TO-7/70 : Microsoft Basic v5, Microsoft assembler and SOLI Logo. They want to make us believe that architects used TO-7/70 ! <br><br> As usual there are no cables shown... The arm looks weird, lifeless... did they cut it to take the picture more easily ?! or is the woman completely laid down on the table ?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OFFICIAL FLYER (RECTO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mainbyte.com" target="_blank">www.mainbyte.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Hyperion is a true portable weighting in at only 18 pounds. It is light on the eyes with its European amber screen and styling. But heavy on performances with many standard features which are expensive necessities for other personal computers. And all for a price that's less that you'd expect...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD. </strong></font><br><blockquote>The red part shows all the IBM-PC software boxes the VP could run.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tim_K for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computing today to be ready for tomorrow"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (AUG. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says: <br><br><font color="#666666"> In other words, how to pop your office into a shoulder bag and then go out and about.<br> You see the Sharp PC7000 is no ordinary computer. Not only it is light, compact body packed with a much speed and power as most desk top computers, it's also very, very versatile... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (NOV. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Enter the game of computing"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert shows all the tools a software developer could run on the MorthStar computers range (Horizon and Advantage) </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 1</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Right now, your computer for today"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
This computer is a Wordprocessor system which looks like an Apple Macintosh (but is not a Macintosh compatible).
It can work with CP/M. Though it was designed as a word processing computer, it has no mouse (go figure !).
It has a graphical user interface and has special keys to use with the word processor (cut/paste, move line/word etc.).
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard with arrow keys and editing keypad
computer.name: Series 35 Model 10

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the rear of the monitor which houses the whole computer and disk-drives, just like with the Apple Macintosh. There is an ON/OFF switch, two device connectors and a Printer interface.</blockquote>
